Dear Megan Zambiasi:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, adverse action is recommended and a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days.
A six-month provisional license is recommended. You must contest or agree to
the issuance of a provisional license in writing, on the CWL-4617 within 30 days. If you
do not submit the CWL-4617, it will be treated as contested. Even if you contest the
issuance of a provisional license, you must still submit an acceptable corrective action
plan.

with any questions.

III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 6/7/24 staff pushed, pulled, cornered, sandwiched, hip-
checked and body blocked Youth T multiple times potentially
causing multiple bruises on her arms.
Investigation Interviews:
I notified Complainant of this investigation assignment. She said
she did not witness the incident on 6/7/24.
I notified Youth T’s JJ Worker of the investigation, and she
expressed no additional concerns.
I interviewed Youth T jointly with Government Worker on 6/10/24.
She has been at the facility for six months and is on probation.
Youth T said she had an “issue” with Supervisor the day before
the incident. On 6/7/24 she was displaying behaviors in the living
area that prompted staff to clear her peers from the space. “I was
yelling and kicking the exit door. Staff 1 and Staff 2 restrained me.
Supervisor came and switched with Staff 1. I understand how
restraints go. Supervisor grabbed me wrong and pinched my arm,
so I basically hit her…I don’t know where. Maybe in the chest.
Supervisor switched out with Team Leader.” Team Leader
mentioned they were in the camera’s blind spot which implied to
Youth T that “she could do whatever she wanted” to her. At that
point she said Team Leader pinched her right bicep causing at
least one bruise. Youth T heard someone say they were pressing
charges against her for assaulting staff. Then the police arrived
but did not question her. She is worried about getting new
charges and wants to stay at Vista Maria and not go to detention.
Youth T said she had bruises on her arms immediately after the
incident but refused to allow staff to check her arms. Afterward
she was transported to Garden City Hospital for a psychiatric
evaluation and ineligible for inpatient hospitalization. At the
2

hospital, she showed hospital personnel the bruises on her arms
and said they did not provide any treatment. Today on 6/10/24,
she said Vista Maria’s Nurse saw the bruises on her arms, took
photos and offered her ice.
Government Worker and I observed and photographed
approximately eleven green and brown bruises on Youth T’s inner
and outer right bicep, inner and outer right forearm, inner left bicep
and inner left forearm.
On 6/13/24 I interviewed Staff 2 jointly with Government Worker
with Rights Officer present. She has worked at the facility for over
a year and was last trained in CPI in March 2024. She was
unable to present an understandable sequence of events
regarding the incident. From what I could surmise, Staff 2 said
she and Staff 1 were in the living area when Youth T threw two
chairs and banged on an exit door until the screws fell out. Staff
1, Staff 2 and Team Leader physically prevented Youth T from
breaking handles off several doors. Supervisor arrived and Youth
T hit Supervisor in her face. Supervisor and Staff 2 took Youth T’s
arms and held them by her side, then Team Leader and Staff 1
switched out and relieved them. Youth T struggled, then stopped
briefly and was released. Staff 1 and Staff 2 verbally tried to de-
escalate her while standing in front of a door to prevent Youth T
from kicking it. Youth T swung at Team Leader and hit Staff 2 in
her chest. Staff 2 left the area. Youth T spit on Team Leader and
Team Leader left the area. Staff 2 was called back to assist
again. Staff 2 denied she mishandled Youth T and denied seeing
any other staff mishandle her.
On 6/18/24 I interviewed Staff 1 jointly with Government Worker
and Rights Officer present. She has worked at the facility over a
year and was last trained in CPI in November 2023. Staff 1 said
Youth T has a history of kicking doors and breaking door handles
at Vista Maria. She recalled that for an hour on 6/7/24, Youth T
paced, hit Supervisor, would not respond to verbal redirection and
moved from door handle to door handle trying to break them.
“From our training, when youths try to destroy property, we are
supposed to go into a hold. Me and Staff 2 pushed Youth T away
(from doors and door handles) …We were trained to get her away
from that area or hold her…Me and Team Leader were
sandwiching her.”
On 6/18/24 I interviewed Supervisor jointly with Government
Worker and Rights Officer present. She is the afternoon
Supervisor at the facility and has over 25 years of experience
3

working with youths in residential facilities. Supervisor was last
trained in CPI in January 2024.
Government Worker read the allegation aloud. Supervisor shed
tears several times as she recalled Youth T’s behaviors on 6/7/24.
She stated Youth T was upset for unknown reasons and reached
up to tear the hinge cover off a door. “I blocked it, and Youth T
punched me three times in the chest. I grabbed her wrist and
placed her in a two-person hold with Staff 1 because she was
dangerous to others. Youth T struggled and got out of the hold.
Staff 2 came and switched out with me. I called 911…because
Youth T was escalated, assaulted Team Leader and I, and
needed an inpatient psych evaluation. Youth T hit door handles
and Team Leader and Staff 1 put her in another two-person hold.
Youth T struggled and dropped to her knees, so they let go.”
When police arrived, Supervisor said she and Team Leader
informed them they wanted to press charges against Youth T for
assaulting them, but she does not believe the youth was charged.
She was frustrated that neither the mental health system nor the
legal system could be relied upon to intervene.
Supervisor denied hearing Team Leader say anything about being
in a blind spot. She said the physical restraint moves she
performed and witnessed others perform were in line with the
agency’s behavior management protocol. When the incident
lasting nearly an hour ended, Supervisor said Youth T refused
debriefing and a body check. Although she did not see any
bruises on Youth T, she said bruising would be possible due to the
hand placement of staff and pressure that must be applied when a
youth struggles against a hold. “If the hold is loose, they (youths)
pull out,” she explained.
Supervisor added that previously Youth T caused so much
damage to the facility that it had to be closed for six weeks for
repairs and it just reopened the day before this incident. Rights
Officer confirmed that new walls were built, and existing ones
were reinforced totaling 100K and that Youth T had caused most
of the damage.
I reminded Supervisor the licensing rule effective May 2022
indicates physical restraint is to only be utilized as a lifesaving
response and that property damage no longer constitutes
justification for physical intervention/restraint. Supervisor said she
believes the door handles in the facility are “too easy to break.”
Further she indicated unidentified superiors told her that property
4

damage should be prevented as it can cause harm to the
resident(s) and preventing it implies restricting the youth’s
freedom of movement if necessary.
On 6/18/24 I interviewed Team Leader jointly with Government
Worker and Rights Officer present. She has worked for the
agency for 21 years and was last trained in CPI in March 2024.
Government Worker read the allegation aloud. Team Leader
summarized that on 6/7/24, Youth T was kicking doors, trying to
break door handles and attacking staff with a closed fist. “She hit
me and Supervisor… in my head and she also spat on me.”
Team Leader said she stepped between Youth T and a door and
Youth T hit her. She and Staff 1 restrained Youth T with Team
Leader on her right side and Staff 1 on her left. Youth T dropped
her weight and was released. “We never got her into a full hold.
She struggled, wiggled and broke out. Then she kicked other
doors and tried to break the kitchen door handle…Youth T was
not injured.” I asked Team Leader if she and Staff 1 restrained
Youth T to prevent her from destroying property. She stated, “We
were told we are supposed to stop youths from hitting walls
because they can severely injure themselves and we are
supposed to block them from destroying property.” Team Leader
said she left the area after Youth T spat in her face and on her
back. “Since they remodeled the building after Youth T caused
100K worth of damage, they put wood behind the walls. Unit
Manager said if kids are hitting or kicking (doors/walls), it’s
automatic physical management because they can hurt
themselves.” Team Leader denied saying anything to Youth T
about a blind spot on the unit adding “I just moved here from
another building. I don’t even know where the blind spots are.”
I interviewed Nurse jointly with Government Worker and Rights
Officer present. On 6/10/24, she said Youth T showed her bruises
on her arms and told her they were caused by a restraint over the
weekend. Nurse offered ice packs and pain medication to the
youth, but Youth T refused them.
Rights Officer added that Youth T was restrained on 6/6/24 the
day before this incident after hitting staff, throwing chairs, flipping
tables, kicking and hitting walls with no injuries documented or
reported. He said no body chart was completed on 6/6/24
because the youth was immediately transported to the hospital for
a psychiatric evaluation, found ineligible for inpatient treatment
and returned to Vista Maria.
5

Video on 6/7/24:
The video begins with Youth T and Staff 2 in a room with nothing
but two loveseats. Around the perimeter of the room, there are
seven locked doors - six leading to other rooms and one directly
outdoors. The video has no audio.
5:58pm – Youth T wheels a chair across the floor from one side of
the room to the other. Staff 2 follows behind her. Youth T sits in
the chair. Staff 2 grabs Youth T under her right armpit and pulls
her out of the chair onto the floor. Youth T falls on her buttocks.
Staff 2 wheels the chair away from Youth T and guards it. Staff 2
pushes Youth T with her hip as Youth T moves toward the chair.
Staff 1 enters the room.
6:00pm – Youth T walks toward a secure interior door. Staff 2
grabs Youth T’s right elbow to stop her, releases her arm and
follows her out of the camera’s view. Both return to the camera.
Youth T paces the room while Staff 2 follows behind her. Staff 2
appears to be talking to Youth T.
6:00pm-6:06pm – Youth T is pacing the room and hallway with
Staff 2 following her around and occasionally talking to her.
6:06pm – Team Leader enters the room with Youth T still pacing.
6:07pm – Staff 2 standing in the doorway between the room and
hallway and gently pushes Youth T to prevent her from entering
the hallway. They pace and Youth T goes in the corner under the
camera. As she walks out of the corner Staff 2 gives her a non-
aggressive push on the arm, she continues to pace and Staff 2
again gives a soft push on the arm as Youth T nears the doorway.
6:08pm – Youth T moves from one secure door to the next
appearing to attempt to break the door handles. Staff 1 appears to
be grabbing Youth T’s arm and pulling it back and then pushing
Youth T towards the wall in an attempt to get her away from the
door.
6:09pm - Youth T moves to a secure door, backs up to it and kicks
it backward alternating feet. Staff 1 and Staff 2 position
themselves on the both sides of Youth T and attempt a two-
person control hold on her and have her bent over, with one staff
on each side holding her arm. They move with Youth T through
the doorway while she is struggling. Staff 1 releases and Youth T
6

falls backwards against the door frame. They attempt another hold
and are unsuccessful.
6:11pm – Supervisor enters the room. Youth T is still kicking her
feet backward against the door with staff standing by.
6:12pm - Youth T goes under the camera; Team Lead follows and
pushes her elbow and upper arm into Youth T. Staff 2 grabs
Youth’s right arm and pulls her from the corner and pushes her
into the wall. Staff 1 then pushes Youth T. Youth T walks away,
then walks back and Staff 1 pushes her away again. Staff 1 then
pushes Youth T into Staff 2, who pushes Youth T toward the
doorway. Youth T appears to be trying to get at the door Staff 1 is
standing against and Staff 1 repeatedly pushes her away.
6:13pm – Youth T is near a door in the hallway. Team Leader and
Staff 1 grab her arms and are each pulling back and forth. They
then get a hold on her arms and bend her over at the waste.
Supervisor appears to be putting weight on Youth T’s back to
keep her bent over. Youth T goes backwards onto the ground, in a
sitting position. Staff continue to hold her arms while she is trying
to crawl away on the floor and then they let go.
6:14pm – Youth T moves in to the corner and Team Lead follows,
pushing her elbow into Youth T. Youth T walks away, moves to a
door and appears to be trying to get something from the top of the
door. Supervisor pushers Youth T’s arms off the door. Youth T
walks over to another door, Team Leader pushes Youth T towards
the door, and Youth T begins kicking the door backwards.
Team Leader approaches her alone, attempts to grab her
arm/wrist and they start flailing their arms at one another. Team
Leader is elbowing Youth T and Staff 1 grabs Youth T’s left arm
and pulls her way. They both push Youth T away from the wall.
6:15pm – Youth T goes back to the door in the hallway and Team
Leader and Staff 1 follow her. She is pulling on the door handle
and Team Leader is trying to push her away from the door. Both
staff use their bodies to keep Youth T in the corner. It should be
noted that both staff are sizably larger than Youth T. Youth T gets
out of the corner and Team Leader swings her hand out at Youth
T. Youth T walks into the room again and to another door in the
corner. Team Leader follows and immediately begins elbowing
Youth T and pushes her.
6:16pm – Staff 1, Staff 2 and Team Leader stand between Youth
T and her targeted doors. As Youth T approaches each door, the
7

staff use their arms to push her ping-pong style back and forth
between them and then into the room. Youth T attempts to go
through the doorway and Staff 1 shoves her. Youth T goes back
into the room and Staff 2 is pulling on Youth T to try to move her
then Staff 1 walks over and shovers Youth T.
Supervisor enters the room.
6:17pm – Team Leader and Youth T are in the corner in the
hallway. Youth T appears to be pulling at the doorknob again and
Team Leader pushes Youth T. Youth T begins kicking another
door backwards and Staff 1 and Supervisor stand on either side of
Youth T. Supervisor tries to get a hold on Youth T’s arm but Youth
T pulls away and Staff 1 pushes her. Youth T tries to go back to
the door that Supervisor and Staff 1 are standing in front of and
grabs the door knob. Supervisor pulls Youth T’s arm backwards
and up while Staff 2 pulls Youth T’s hand off the door knob, then
they release Youth T.
6:18pm – Youth T goes under the camera and begins backward
kicking the door. Staff 1 and Staff 2 walk over and Youth T walks
away. Both staff following as she nears the doorway to the hallway
They begin pushing her and Staff 1 grabs Youth T’s sweatshirt
and they push her into the hallway and into the corner. They all
struggle and Youth T falls to the ground. Youth T gets up and
paces the room. Staff 1 gives her a push away from the door. She
goes to another door where Staff 1 pulls her by her arm away from
it. Staff 1 proceeds to push with her arms and use her body weight
several more times. Staff 1 comes over and pushes as well. Staff
1 continues to push Youth T and attempts to trip her. Youth T then
paces around walking from door to door.
6:23pm – Youth T goes under the camera and can be seen
backward kicking the door. Staff are under the camera, and Staff 2
cannot be seen until her arms extend, pushing Youth T into the
room.
6:24pm – Youth T is pulling on the door knob of the door in the
hallway. Both staff are in the main room watching. Then Staff 1
goes over and pushes Youth T with her hips and shoves her into
the wall.
6:25pm – Youth T walks over another wall to the window and Staff
2 follows. Staff 2 pushes Youth T a few times. Youth T walks back
to the other wall, followed by Staff 2, and is backward kicking the
8

door. Staff 2’s arms can be seen pushing Youth T. Staff 1 comes
over and pulls Youth T’s arm.
6:26pm – Staff 1 and 2 both keep touching and holding Youth T’s
arm as she has her back against the door and eventually push her
into the room. She walks towards the corner and Staff 2 pushes
her. She is standing with her back against the door and Staff 1
pushes her twice and then shoves her toward Staff 2.
6:27pm – Staff 2 is repeatedly pushing on Youth T and then
shoves her. Youth T paces the room and into the hallway, pulling
on the door knob again. Staff 2 walks over, blocks the doorway,
wraps her arms around Youth T who had went around her, and
then Staff 1 pulled both of Youth T’s arms back and let go.
6:28pm – Youth T crosses the room and is standing near a door,
but not doing anything. Staff 2 approaches and pushes Youth T
with her hips and then pushes her against the door, continuing to
try to hold her there against her struggles. The door opens and
Staff 2 enters, which pushes Youth T towards Staff 1 whose arms
are outstretched toward Youth T, and Youth T swings her arms at
Staff 1. Staff 1 grabs Youth T and bends over the couch at her
waist pushing on her head to keep her down. She releases two
seconds later.
6:29pm - Team Leader enters the room and Youth T walks over to
that door and shoves Team Leader. Team Leader and Staff 2 are
struggling with Youth T; each have an arm and they are pulling
back and forth. At 24:49 Staff 2 walks away. Team Leader
continues to hold Youth T’s arms to prevent her from moving, in
unapproved holds, and using her body weight to push Youth T
against the wall with Youth T’s arm pinned behind her back
against the wall until 32:49.
6:32pm – Team Leader forces Youth T into a corner and uses her
body weight to hold her there. Youth T and Team Leader are
back-to-back with Youth T facing the corner and Team Leader
facing the center of the room. Staff 1 joins Team Leader and
sandwiches Youth T against the wall, pinning her with her hips for
two minutes. Youth T is released.
6:34pm – Another round of ping-ponging begins with staff pushing
and shoving Youth T into the center of the room away from interior
locked doors.
9

6:35pm – Youth T crosses the room to where Team Leader is
standing along the wall. As Youth T approaches, Team Leader
shoves Youth T, who swings back, and Team Leader pushes
Youth T into the corner using her body weight on her. Staff 1 joins
and puts one arm on Youth T’s back to push her down so she‘s
bending forward at the waist and holds Youth T’s arm with her
other hand. After several seconds they let Youth T go.
6:36pm – Youth T is standing against a door and Team Leader
stands next to her and pushes her briefly. Youth T walks away
and is looking through the window. As soon as Youth T walks
away towards another door Team Leader goes over and tries to
block Youth T’s access to the door and then shoves Youth T.
6:38pm – Team Leader and Staff 1 execute a two-person control
hold until Youth T drops her weight to the floor, and they release.
6:39pm – Youth T paces for the next minute and then when she
approaches the door in the hallway Team Leader walks over and
pushes her against the wall. She then bends her over again and
has her arm on Youth T’s back holding her down. Staff 1 followed
and is watching this interaction. Youth T can be seen trying to
stand up and Team Leader keeps pushing her down. Team
Leader single-handedly pins Youth T to the wall using her whole
body again. Staff 2 comes back in. Team Leader walks away and
Staff 2 pushes Youth T against the wall. Youth T struggles and
Staff 1 grabs Youth T’s right arm and they struggle back and forth
with Youth T. Staff 1 uses her back end to push Youth T into the
corner and both staff hold her. Youth T starts to break through
them at 6:42 and they shove Youth T forward.
6:42pm – Youth T is released and resumes pacing the room. Staff
1 and 2 continue to follow her around the room. When she is
between the room and the hallway, Staff 1 pushes Youth T into
the wall and both staff grab hold of Youth T’s arms in a control
hold and then immediately shove her forward. Staff 2 follows and
appears to be talking to Youth T who is out of camera view. She
comes back into view and Staff 2 pushes her again.
6:44pm – Youth T is pacing in the small hallway area and Staff 1
and Staff 2 are blocking the entrance back into the room. Youth T
walks toward them and Staff 1 extends her arm to push her back,
without force. Staff 2 can be seen talking to Youth T. Youth T
resume pacing and then tries to enter the room between the two
staff and they both push her back. Youth T tries again and Staff 1
extends an arm again. Youth T can be seen talking to them during
10

this time. Youth continues pacing in that small area until 6:50pm
with staff blocking the doorway and then Staff 2 walks away.
Youth T continues pacing for another minute and the video ends.
Documents reviewed:
An incident report by Supervisor dated 6/7/24 indicated Youth T
appeared upset when Staff 1 asked her for a hug. Youth T threw
chairs and staff cleared the area of other youths. Youth T called
Staff 1 a “hoe” and continued using profanity. Staff 1 tried to
persuade Youth T to go to her room to no avail. Youth T pulled on
a door handle and went door-to-door kicking. Team Leader
entered the wing to assist. Youth T shook on the door handles
trying to break them. Team Leader escorted her away and she
continued kicking doors. Youth T headed for the crossover door
and shook the door handle. Team Leader again blocked her from
shaking it. Supervisor relieved Team Leader by standing in front
of the door to prevent Youth T from kicking it. Youth T hit
Supervisor with a closed fist three times. Supervisor and Team
Leader attempted CPI (Crisis Prevention Institute) team control
technique and were unsuccessful due to Youth T continuing to try
to assault Supervisor. Supervisor switched out with Team Leader
again. Supervisor contacted police at 6:18pm. Youth T
aggressively punched Team Leader in the head at approximately
6:36 pm. Youth T was placed in a team control hold with Team
Leader on the right and Staff 2 on the left. Team Leader
continued to try to use de-escalation techniques still to no avail.
Youth T went to the kitchen door and tried to break the handle.
Team Leader stepped in front of the door to block her. Youth T
tried to aggressively move Team Leader out of the way. Youth T
spat in Team Leader’s face. Staff 1 switched out with Team
Leader. Youth T spit on the back of Team Leader’s shirt. Youth T
continued to be aggressive towards staff. Staff 1 and Staff 2
placed Youth T in a low hold, the youth dropped to the floor, and
they disengaged. Youth T began to calm down.
A body chart completed by Staff 1 on 6/7/24 identified two bruises
on each of Youth T’s inner wrists.
A body chart completed by Staff 4 on 6/9/24 identified 18 bruises
on the front and back of both of Youth T arms in addition to the
two on her inner wrists identified by Staff 1 on 6/7/24.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance with this rule as pushing,
shoving, hip-checking, cornering, sandwiching, body blocking and
bending over a couch or bending a youth over and pushing on
them to hold them down Is prohibited. Staff 1, Staff 2 and Team
11

Leader engaged in these behaviors throughout the course of
almost a full hour.
CONSULTATION
On 6/19/24 I recommended in an email to Chief Administrator that
Vista Maria remove all hand lever door locks which are easily
broken and offer low security and replace them with cylinder locks
which are more resilient and offer increased security.
Conclusion Repeat Violations Established
2024C0001126SI intake 2/07/24; CAP approved 3/12/24.
2024SIC0001184 intake 2/23/24; CAP approved 3/25/24.
2024C0001153SI intake 2/15/24; CAP approved 4/22/24.
2024SIC0001304 intake 4/3/24; CAP pending.
Rule Code Emergency restraint
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4160
Section (1) The use of emergency restraint as a lifesaving response for a
Description youth will be limited to:
(a) An emergency response to protect the youth or others from
an unanticipated or severely aggressive behavior that places the
youth or others at serious threat of violence or injury if no
immediate intervention occurs.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth T was physically managed to prevent property damage
rather than as an emergency or life-saving response.
Investigation Interviews:
Staff 2 described how Staff1, Team Leader and herself physically
intervened to prevent Youth T from breaking handles off several
doors.
Staff 1 stated “From our training, when youths try to destroy
property, we are supposed to go into a hold. Me and Staff 2
pushed Youth T away (from doors and door handles) …We were
trained to get her away from that area or hold her.”
Supervisor said Youth T hit door handles and Team Leader and
Staff 1 put her in a two-person hold. She said her superiors told
12

her that property damage should be prevented because it can
cause harm to resident(s) and that prevention implies physically
restricting the youth’s movement when necessary.
Team Leader explained “We (staff) were told we are supposed to
stop youths from hitting walls because they can severely injure
themselves and we are supposed to block them from destroying
property…Unit Manager said if kids are hitting or kicking
(doors/walls), it’s an automatic physical management because
they could hurt themselves.”
I interviewed Unit Manager jointly via video conference on
6/26/24 with Government Worker and Rights Officer present. He
has been a CPI trainer at Vista Maria for 18 months. He said he
began supervising Team Leader and Supervisor on 6/16/24, but
he was not their supervisor when this incident took place.
Unit Manager listed four situations in which staff may and should
initiate physical restraint. 1) When a youth is in the process of
assaulting a peer; 2) When the youth is in the process of
assaulting staff; 3) When a youth is in the process of harming
themselves and 4) To remove an item in the youth’s possession
that can be used as a weapon.
I asked Unit Manager how staff are taught to intervene when a
youth is attempting to destroy property or is in the process of
destroying it. He differentiated between two types of scenarios
involving property destruction where timely and nuanced decisions
must be made on the part of staff. For example, when a youth is
kicking property or attempting to break/tear a lock or door handle
off (but has not yet torn it off), he said staff may only verbally
intervene. However, when a youth is in the process of injuring
herself by punching glass or another hard surface or possesses a
hard object such as glass or metal that could be used as a
weapon, staff should then intervene physically and remove the
object to stop her from injuring herself or others.
Video from 6/7/24 was reviewed and the details of the incidents
observed on video are noted above. It shows that there was no life
threatening situation that occurred that resulted in Staff 1, Staff 2,
and Team Leader physically engaging with Youth T, or for
Supervisor to not intervene and stop staff’s actions when they
were observed to be physically engaging with no imminent risk of
harm.
The facility’s Prohibited Behavior Intervention Practices states:
13

They strictly prohibit excessive or inappropriate use of behavior
management intervention. Behavior management interventions
will not be used as a form of discipline or to force compliance, for
the convenience of staff, or for property damage that does not
involve threatening danger to self or others.
Analysis Video showed Youth T approaching locked doors and hand levers
and kicking backward on doors with the flats of her feet. Youth T
did not present an imminent danger to herself or others at these
times. Youth T only became assaultive to staff after Staff 2 pulled
her out of a chair and onto the floor, pushed her away using her
hips, grabbed her arms and followed her around a relatively small,
secure room; which occurred repeatedly and over an extended
period of time. Additionally, staff followed Youth T around the
room for an hour, which was inappropriate and did not serve to
settle Youth T down. Had Staff 2 not pulled her from the chair and

Youth T’s hits and push towards staff were in response to staff
being repeatedly inappropriately physical with her.
One staff stated they must physically “block” youths to stop them
from damaging property. Two others said they believed they were
allowed to use physical intervention to prevent property damage.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Youth T was already in a secure confined space, so it was futile
for staff to hold or attempt to hold her only to release her back into
the same space before her behaviors de-escalated. Holding a
youth for the sole purpose of keeping her away from secure
objects such as doors and handles is neither permitted, nor
sustainable. Pushing, hip-checking, cornering, sandwiching and
body blocking a youth is prohibited in all situations. However, in
this case, staff restricted Youth T’s movements not to protect her
or themselves, but to reportedly protect property.
